facts.text: In the 1957 general elections, nine persons filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Sathankulam constituency, all found valid on scrutiny.
Among the candidates were the appellant (returned candidate), respondent Kandaswami, R. Meganathan, and G. E. Muthu.
Meganathan, Muthu, and three others dropped out of the election before the poll.
The election was contested by the appellant, respondent Kandaswami, and two other candidates.
Appellant was successful at the poll and declared elected on March 6, 1957.
On April 15, 1957, respondent Kandaswami filed an election petition under the Representation of the People Act, 1951, for declaration that appellant's election was void.
Appellant made respondent No. 1 to the petition; Meganathan and Muthu not made parties; some other candidates made parties.
Petition referred to Election Tribunal for trial.
Appellant applied to Election Tribunal (I.A. No. 1 of 1957) for dismissal of petition under s.90(3) for non-compliance with s.82.
Appellant's contention: Allegations of corrupt practice against Meganathan and Muthu in petition, so they should be parties under s.82(b).
Tribunal dismissed appellant's application, accepting respondent's view that no allegations of corrupt practice against Meganathan or Muthu.
Appellant filed applications in Madras High Court for writ of certiorari quashing Tribunal's order and writ of prohibition against proceeding with petition.
Madras High Court dismissed both applications on November 1, 1957.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate granted by Madras High Court.

Election petition allegation (para IV-A): Returned candidate (appellant) and election agent paid gift of Rs.10,000 to Meganathan to induce withdrawal from Sathankulam, and he withdrew; paid gratification of Rs.5,000 to Muthu to retire from contest, and he retired.
Meganathan and Muthu were candidates as defined in s.79 of the Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether the statements in the election petition that Meganathan and Muthu accepted money from the returned candidate to induce them to withdraw from the contest and they did so, constitute allegations of corrupt practice against them requiring them to be joined as respondents under s.82(b) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: Petition liable to be dismissed for non-joinder of Muthu and Meganathan, who were candidates; allegation that Meganathan accepted gift of Rs.10,000 and withdrew candidature, Muthu accepted Rs.5,000 gratification and retired from contest, constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(1).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 ss.79(b), 82(b), 98, 99, 123(1); Transfer of Property Act (gift is bilateral act)

petitioner_arguments.text: Words 'by a candidate or his agent or by any other person' in s.123(1) to be read with 'offer or promise' not 'gift'; gift includes acceptance.
s.99 requires finding on corrupt practice committed with consent of candidate; acceptance with object to withdraw shows consent, so liable to be named.
Gratification in s.123 wide, includes withdrawal of candidature by candidate to induce another to stand.
s.82(b) contemplates any allegation relating to or concerning a corrupt practice.

respondent_arguments.text: Candidate accepting gift from returned candidate does not commit corrupt practice under s.123(1); not necessary party under s.82(b).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(1), s.82(b); s.124(3) deleted by Amending Act XXVII of 1956

respondent_arguments.text: s.123(1) defines bribery as gift, offer or promise by candidate/agent/other; does not include acceptance; words contemplate making of gift.
Deletion of s.124(3) (receipt of gratification as minor corrupt practice) without change to s.123(1) shows acceptance no longer corrupt practice.
s.99 does not define corrupt practice; must read with s.123 definition.

court_reasoning.text: Allegations against Meganathan and Muthu: they accepted money to drop out and did so; is this allegation of corrupt practice against them?
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court held no, only giving of bribe is corrupt practice, not acceptance; Court agrees.

court_reasoning.text: s.123(1) defines bribery as gift, offer or promise by candidate/agent/other with object of inducing withdrawal etc.; acceptance not included; words contemplate making of gift, not acceptance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object is of giver, not receiver.

court_reasoning.text: Deletion of s.124(3) (receipt/agreement to receive as corrupt practice) without amending s.123(1) shows legislature intended acceptance not to be corrupt practice.
Gift under Transfer of Property Act bilateral, but legislature can attach consequences to giving alone; has done so.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acceptance deliberately omitted from corrupt practices.

court_reasoning.text: s.99 does not define corrupt practice; consent to corrupt practice (as defined in s.123) committed by another is not itself a corrupt practice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allegation of consent not allegation that candidate committed corrupt practice.

court_reasoning.text: Withdrawal as gratification to induce another to stand not alleged; even if, not helpful.
s.82(b) means allegations that candidate committed corrupt practice; imputes default to him; acceptance does not relate to corrupt practice (which is giving).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to join Meganathan and Muthu.

holdings.text: Acceptance of a gift (bribe) by a candidate to induce withdrawal is not a corrupt practice under s.123(1) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Allegations in the petition do not constitute allegations of corrupt practice against Meganathan and Muthu; no need to join them as parties under s.82(b).

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines candidates, parties to petition, dismissal for non-compliance, corrupt practices (bribery), findings on corrupt practices with consent

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Gift is bilateral act involving giving and acceptance, but legislature can penalize giving alone

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The Supreme Court holds that the election petition does not contain allegations of corrupt practice against Meganathan and Muthu, so no non-compliance with s.82(b); Tribunal and High Court orders upheld; election petition to proceed.

key_quotes.text: "Is an acceptance of a bribe... a corrupt practice within this definition? We do not think it is."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s.123(1) excluding acceptance

key_quotes.text: "By omitting s.124(3) from the Act therefore the legislature intended that acceptance of a bribe was no longer to be treated as a corrupt practice."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Section 99 does not purport to define a corrupt practice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument linking s.99 to defining acceptance as corrupt practice

key_quotes.text: "Allegations of corrupt practice against a candidate must mean that the candidate was guilty of corrupt practice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
